raw_text:
UKIP MEP attacked German 'empire'
 
 A UK Independence Party MEP suggested Germany saw the EU as an 'empire' and was cheaper than using tanks, a new documentary has revealed. Mike Nattrass, UKIP's deputy leader, made the comments to an audience at a meeting during last September's Hartlepool by-election campaign. But challenged on the remark, he denied accusing Germany of using the EU as cover for a "4th German Reich". He says he was not "German-bashing" but saying peace was the EU's founding aim. The meeting was shown in a BBC 3 film on ex-UKIP MEP Robert Kilroy-Silk. The former chat show host quit the party earlier this month, calling it a joke.
 
 The documentary showed Mr Nattrass, apparently talking about the EU, telling the meeting: "The Germans are the big losers here but they don't care because to them the project is worthwhile. "It's like an empire for them spreading in all directions away from Germany into Hungary, into what they call the Sudetenland - Czechoslovakia, places like that. "So it's cheaper for them to do it this way than roll the tanks in." On Tuesday, he told the BBC News website he did not think the comments were offensive and worked happily with MEPs of different nationalities in the European Parliament. He argued that peace was the only reason for having the "outdated" EU as there was no economic justification. Pointing to Germany's trade interests as a country in the centre of Europe, Mr Nattrass said: "The fact is that the EU benefits Germany but it does not benefit Britain. "I'm not at all German-bashing. It's the truth." A UKIP spokesman said: "Mike has some passionate beliefs and sometimes uses excessively colourful language with which to express them."
 
 The documentary showed some of the tensions between Mr Kilroy-Silk and his fellow MEPs after UKIP took third place in last year's European elections. He denied wanting to be leader until October 2004, when he told BBC One's Breakfast with Frost programme he aspired to the job. Asked by the documentary makers why he had lied about his leadership ambitions, Mr Kilroy-Silk said: "There was one thing I said that I shouldn't have said at the time. "I was trying to be helpful to the party and it was the wrong thing to do, I should have told the truth." The film also included footage of a row between Mr Kilroy-Silk, MEP Nigel Farage and party leader Roger Knapman about rumours that he was about to resign the UKIP whip in the European Parliament. Mr Kilroy-Silk told them he had not left the UKIP group - a move he announced shortly after the meeting. He told Mr Farage: "Don't tell lies Nigel, now you've told too many. Most of the trouble had been caused by you." UKIP officials claim it was in fact Mr Kilroy-Silk, not Mr Farage, who briefed newspapers he was leaving the group of MEPs.
 
 Later in unguarded, off-air comments in a television studio, Mr Kilroy-Silk was heard saying he was irritated by "defending some of these right-wing fascist nutters". Mr Kilroy-Silk separately said he had argued against UKIP working with such groups which believed homosexuality was a sin. A UKIP spokesman said there were more than 40 MEPs in the same group in the European Parliament. They were from a broad spectrum - some right-wing, some left-wing - but with a shared belief in the "unfeasibility of the EU as it is now". He did not defend other groups' religious beliefs but argued it was their right to hold such views - just as Mr Kilroy-Silk had a right to criticise Arab states. London UKIP MEP Gerard Batten said: "Robert has made a variety of comments about UKIP and its MEPs. "There are of course two sides to every story. What Robert does not say is that he was offered several positions which would have given him effective control of the party, but not the title of leader." Mr Kilroy-Silk is to launch his own parry, Veritas, in Westminster on Wednesday.
llama3.2:1b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass suggested Germany sees the EU as an "empire" and cheaper than using tanks during a meeting last September.
He claimed Germany benefits economically but does not benefit Britain.
A documentary showed him saying Germany's trade interests are at the centre of Europe, while UKIP officials deny he was trying to be helpful.
The film also included footage of tensions between UKIP members and Robert Kilroy-Silk, who denies being German-bashing.
llama3.2:3b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass suggested Germany views the EU as an "empire" and finds it cheaper than using tanks to expand its territory.
He denied accusing Germany of using the EU as cover for a fourth German Reich.

Former UKIP chat show host Robert Kilroy-Silk's documentary shows tensions between him and fellow MEPs, including Nigel Farage, over his comments on right-wing groups and his decision to leave the party's group in the European Parliament.
gemma2:2b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass made comments comparing Germany's role within the EU to an "empire," stating it was cheaper for them to utilize this approach than deploying tanks.

Nattrass denies accusations of "German-bashing" and maintains that peace was the reason for the EU's existence, while UKIP officials acknowledge his use of colorful language but defend him as passionate.

Former UKIP MEP Robert Kilroy-Silk, who recently resigned, is shown in a documentary to have been involved in clashes with party members regarding leadership ambitions and rumors about his departure from the group.
Kilroy-Silk also expresses irritation at those he calls "right-wing fascist nutters" while claiming he opposed working with groups holding similar views.
A UKIP spokesperson highlights the diversity within the MEP group, acknowledging its diverse political leanings and defending Kilroy-Silk's right to express his opinion.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass accused German 'empire' after saying Germans are more interested in peace than tanks.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Mike Nattrass, UKIP MEP and deputy leader, suggested Germany views EU as an "empire" due to peace founding aim; denied accusing Germany of using EU for a 4th German Reich; former chat host quit party earlier this month after calling it joke.
qwen2.5:3b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass suggested Germany viewed the EU as an "empire" and cheaper than military action, calling it a way for Germany to spread its influence across Europe.
He denied accusations of "German-bashing," stating that peace was the main reason for the EU's existence.

The documentary also revealed tensions between UKIP MEPs over leadership issues, with Robert Kilroy-Silk resigning from his position and making controversial statements about the party's alignment with extremist groups.
opencoder:1.5b: A UK Independence Party MEP, who attacked a German 'empire', suggested Germany saw the EU as an 'empire' and was cheaper than using tanks, has revealed more about the European Union's role in Europe than any given statements could capture.
While the documentary details various points of contention, it doesn't elaborate on the main points raised by the UKIP MEP.
The documentary does not make clear that Germany is "German-bashing", and he argues that peace was the EU's founding aim.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Mike Nattrass, a UK Independence Party MEP, made comments during an election campaign suggesting Germany was seen as an "empire" using tanks and being cheaper than other options.
He denied claiming it was "4th German Reich," referring to peace as the EU's goal.
His remarks were seen in a BBC 3 documentary featuring his statements: "The Germans are big losers here but they don't care because their project is worthwhile."
He emphasized that Germany spreads its empire outward, reducing costs via tanks.
On the other side, Robert Kilroy-Silk denied wanting to be leader until October 2004, when he lied about his intentions.
There was a subplot where he lied too, claiming opposition to groups believing homophobia.
During the documentary, Kilroy-Silk revealed he was part of an EU Parliament group that left him, and told fellow MEPs he wasn't leaving UKIP either.
He argued it was their right to hold differing beliefs.
Later, Kilroy-Silk launched Veritas, a defense against others' parries in Westminster.
tinyllama:1.1b: UKIP MEP Robert Kilroy-Silk has been criticized for making comments suggesting that the EU "was an empire" and used as a "cover for a '4th German Reich'" during a meeting with UKIP supporters in Hartlepool, UK.
According to a BBC documentary, he also accused Germany of using the EU as a cover for spreading their political beliefs to other countries.
In response, UKIP officials stated that Kilroy-Silk made these comments off-air and that he did not defend or attack other groups' religious beliefs.
However, they claimed that he was irritated by "defending some of these right-wing fascist nutters."
Kilroy-Silk has since launched his own party project, Veritas, with the intent to counter the negative perception of UKIP during the upcoming European elections.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The video shows UK Independence Party (UKIP) MEP Mike Nattrass attacking Germany's empire status and the idea that it used tanks as a defense against invasion.
He also criticizes the EU for using the EU to create '4th German Reich'.
The meeting took place in Hartlepool, which saw UKIP gain third place in the European Parliament elections.
The video footage shows Mr Nattrass giving a speech at an event where he accused Germany of having imperial ambitions.
He also referred to the EU as the "four-tiger power," implying that it was dominated by Japan, Russia, and China.
The video further shows him discussing with other party members how peace is better for Germany than using tanks to defend its interests in places like the Sudetenland.
phi:2.7b: A UK Independence Party MEP suggested Germany saw the EU as an "empire" and that using tanks was cheaper than working with it.
He made this comment during a meeting at the Hartlepool by-election campaign, but denied being German-bashing and said he believed peace was the founding aim of the EU.
The remark caused tension between Mr Kilroy-Silk and his fellow MEPs and led to him leaving the party later in the year.

He denied accusing Germany of using the EU as cover for a 4th German Reich but argued that peace was the only reason for having the 'outdated' EU as there was no economic justification.
The documentary showed some tensions between Mr Kilroy-Silk and his fellow MEPs after UKIP took third place in last year's European elections.
He denied wanting to be leader until October 2004, when he told BBC One's Breakfast with Frost programme he aspired to the job.
It was later revealed that he had briefed newspapers he was leaving the UKIP whip in the European Parliament.
Later in unguarded comments in a television studio, Mr Kilroy-Silk said he was irritated by 'defending some of these right-wing fascist nutters'.
He did not defend other groups' religious beliefs but argued it was their right to hold such views - just as Mr Kilroy-Silk had a right to criticize Arab states.
hermes3:3b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass comments Germany views EU as 'empire', cheaper than tanks, according to BBC documentary.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A UKIP MEP, Mike Nattrass, suggested that Germany saw the EU as an "empire" and was cheaper than using tanks.
He denied accusing Germany of using the EU as cover for a "4th German Reich."
Nattrass argued that peace was the only reason for having the EU, as there was no economic justification.
The documentary also showed tensions between UKIP MEP Robert Kilroy-Silk and his fellow MEPs, as well as off-air comments revealing his irritation with certain groups within UKIP.
chatgpt-4o-latest: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass suggested Germany viewed the EU as an empire, expanding economically rather than militarily, but denied accusing Germany of using the EU as a cover for a "4th German Reich."
He argued that the EU primarily benefited Germany, not Britain, and insisted he was not "German-bashing."
A UKIP spokesman acknowledged Nattrass's passionate views and colorful language.
The documentary also highlighted tensions within UKIP, particularly between ex-MEP Robert Kilroy-Silk and other party members.
Kilroy-Silk, who had previously denied leadership ambitions, later admitted he had misled the public.
The film captured disputes between Kilroy-Silk, Nigel Farage, and party leader Roger Knapman over his rumored resignation from the UKIP group in the European Parliament, which he later confirmed.
Off-air, Kilroy-Silk was heard criticizing right-wing elements within UKIP, arguing against working with groups holding extreme views.
UKIP officials defended their broad coalition while acknowledging internal disagreements.
Kilroy-Silk was set to launch his own party, Veritas.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK Independence Party MEP Mike Nattrass suggested Germany sees the EU as an "empire" and found it cheaper than using tanks, a new documentary revealed.
Nattrass made these comments during a meeting campaign for UKIP but later denied the accusation.
He claimed he was not "German-bashing," but stating peace is the EU's founding aim.
Nattrass said that peace was necessary for having the outdated EU as there is no economic justification.
The UKIP spokesman clarified that Nattrass does have passionate beliefs and colorful language, but his views on certain topics are genuine.
granite3.1-dense:2b: UKIP MEP Mike Nattrass, during a 2013 campaign meeting for Hartlepool by-election, suggested that Germany perceives the EU as an "empire" spanning from Germany to Central Europe, making it cheaper than military intervention.
Nattrass denied accusing Germany of using the EU as a cover for a "4th German Reich," stating his intention was not to "German-bash" but to emphasize peace's founding purpose in the EU.

The documentary, featured on BBC 3, also highlighted tensions within UKIP, including Robert Kilroy-Silk denying leadership aspirations and engaging in a heated exchange with Nigel Farage about resignation rumors.
Kilroy-Silk later criticized defending right-wing views on homosexuality as sinful.
UKIP officials clarified that the party's MEP group consists of over 40 members from various ideological backgrounds, united by skepticism about the EU's current structure.
Kilroy-Silk plans to establish a new political party called Veritas in Westminster.
